oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Oak Ridge Boys Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with the Oak Ridge Boys (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Oak Ridge Boys; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Duane Allen tells about how the Oak Ridge Boys, at one time, would listen to ten publishers present their music a day -- (00:38) "An American Family" is discussed by Allen to be a song inspired by a visit to George H. W. Bush -- (01:50) Steve Sanders exemplifies how much time has an effect on the world, and Allen says that disc jockeys tried to pressure the Oak Ridge Boys to create 'up' songs -- (03:19) "Baby, You'll Be My Baby" writer Troy Seals is praised by Sanders and Allen, and Allen mentions the last song they listened to was a Seals' song -- (04:10) Biff Collie speculates on the on the influence Allen's and Sanders' song writing abilities has on musical decision making; Allen and Sanders discuss how they are having issues with recording a Dave Loggins' song -- (05:39) Allen recalls meeting with Noel Fox, and Allen recalls Fox showing him Lionel Cartwright's "I Watched it All on My Radio" -- (6:13) Allen explains how he's a fan of the voices of: J.D. Martin, Robert Kilo, and Roger Murrah -- (07:02) Collie introduces the Oak Ridge Boys and "Bed of Roses;" Allen tries to recall the artist's name for "Bed of Roses" off microphone -- (07:28) "Bed of Roses" writer Rex Benson is discussed by Allen, and Allen expresses how he enjoys songs that can be sung an octave below its initial cut -- (08:39) Collie recites a saying about good songs and Allen refutes Collie's point using Sanders' "Live and Love" as an example -- (11:02) Sanders radio spot introducing the Kentucky Headhunters' "Walk Softly on this Heart of Mine" -- (11:16) Collie introduces the Oak Ridge Boys and "Cajun Girl" and Allen describes how everyone had a good opinion of the song; 'Little Feet' were used in the recording process and Allen tells how one of the sounds was drum sticks on tile -- (13:04) Collie introduces the Oak Ridge Boys as Allen and Sanders do impressions of Richard Sterban and Joe Bonsall -- (13:27) "Don't Give Up" is told by Allen to be written by Jerry Hludzik and Rick Manwiller, and Allen says the inspiration to be by Allen telling Hludzik to create a song based on the word recharge -- (14:44) Sanders, Allen and Collie vocalize "Don't Give Up" while trying to get the engineer John to join them -- (15:34) Allen tells about how he worked on a radio show in college where he sold tickets to see the Oak Ridge Boys -- (16:35) Allen recalls a review that had a glowing review of the shows energy and Allen and Sanders attest to the difficulty to keep up the energy -- (18:13) Allen describes the intense energy of the Kentucky Headhunters -- (18:37) Collie introduces the idea of disc jockeys wanting up-tempo songs, and Allen recalls how "Heart of Mine" was in the top one-hundred played songs; Allen performed a count on the ratio of up-tempo to ballad songs -- (20:09) Allen describes "If I Was to Start Crying" as an 'off the wall' song, and Allen describes the Oak Ridge Boys looking to find humor in their music -- (21:34) Collie introduces the Oak Ridge Boys and Sanders, Allen, and Collie discuss how one feels differently about a song at different times -- (22:35) Allen describes how he thoroughly enjoyed a song [unidentified], but whenever he played it Bonsall would avoid the song -- (23:44) Allen, Collie, and Sanders talk about "Chiseled in Stone" by Vern Gosdin away from the microphone -- (24:19) Allen radio spot introducing "That Just About Does it" by Vern Gosdin -- (24:38) Collie introduces the Oak Ridge Boys and American Dreams; Sanders discusses how "In My Own Crazy Way" had five writers, and that it was a good song for Bonsall vocals -- (25:35) "No Matter How High" is told by Sanders to be one of the last songs in a listening session, and Sanders and Allen joke about how Sanders only recorded the vocals for Allen to record over -- (27:28) "The American Dream" is discussed by Allen to be an example of the last thirty years of living in the United States of America, and Allen tells how the song was written to match what the Oak Ridge Boys had been recording prior -- (28:44) "Turning for Home" is told to be a song specifically written for Allen, and that it's about leaving home only to want to return -- (29:38) Allen says 'Thanks, for the ride'
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Oak Ridge Boys; Collie, Biff;
